unnormalised: I remember the first time I really understood what "404 Not Found" meant. It wasn't just some error message on a screen; it was a digital roadblock on my quest to find a free Bollywood song download. This was back in the early 2000s, pre-Jio, when internet access was as precious as gold and came with a hefty Rs. 200/hour price tag at the local cyber cafe in my hometown, Kanpur.

It wasn't just some error message on a screen; it was a digital roadblock on my quest to find a free Bollywood song download. This was back in the early two thousands, pre-Jio, when internet access was as precious as gold and came with a hefty rupee two hundred per hour price tag at the local cyber cafe in my hometown, Kanpur.

unnormalised: I'd heard whispers from my classmates about this amazing website that supposedly had all the latest Hindi film songs. It was shared via word of mouth, written on the back of a notebook page: www.bollytunes.com/songs. Of course, back then, I didn't understand things like URLs or the importance of checking for typos. Armed with my pocket money, I rushed to the cyber cafe after school.

Of course, back then, I didn't understand things like U-R-Ls or the importance of checking for typos. Armed with my pocket money, I rushed to the cyber cafe after school.

unnormalised: Typing the address with trembling fingers, I hit enter, expecting to be transported to a musical paradise. Instead, that dreaded "404 Not Found" glared back at me. I tried again, and again, each time with the same result. The cyber cafe owner, a kind man with thick glasses, noticed my frustration. "Beta, check the spelling," he advised. "Maybe it's .net, not .com?"

unnormalised: I spent the next 30 minutes trying every possible combination – .in, .org, adding and removing "www." – each attempt ending in failure. That Rs. 100 vanished quickly, leaving me with nothing but a profound understanding of what a "dead link" felt like. And a burning desire to understand how the internet REALLY worked.

unnormalised: Later, a friend explained about DNS servers, how IP addresses actually work, and the whole concept of hosting. My mind was blown. I understood that the "404" wasn't just a random error; it was the web server's polite (or not-so-polite) way of saying, "Sorry, I can't find what you're looking for at that particular 'location' on the internet." It sparked a fascination that eventually led me to pursue a degree in Computer Science.

unnormalised: Years later, I learned about concepts like "URL shortening" using services like TinyURL (tinyurl.com/example) and the ever-present threat of "phishing" via cleverly disguised links sent via SMS or email (like winning a '₹1 Crore Lottery!' - don't click!). "Bandwidth" suddenly became a critical concern, especially during IPL matches when everyone was streaming live on their Jio connections. I even had to explain to my grandma the concept of "Wi-Fi" and why her WhatsApp calls kept dropping at 10:00 PM (peak usage time, I discovered).

Remember my Kanpur cyber cafe experience, and maybe you'll find yourself on a path to understanding something new.
